SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts, tired, fatigued, and lightheaded for the past five weeks. He attributes this to the change in seasons and recent home construction projects. The patient has been experiencing bloating and shortness of breath during exertion. He also reports a slight cough and occasional chest cramps that resolve within an hour. The patient's diet has been off due to kitchen renovations, leading to eating out more frequently.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Positive for fatigue and lightheadedness. No fever or chills.
• Cardiovascular: Positive for shortness of breath during exertion and occasional chest cramps.
• Respiratory: Positive for a slight cough. No wheezing.
• Gastrointestinal: Positive for bloating. No nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygenation within normal limits.
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to about 8 centimeters.
• Cardiovascular: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in lungs.

Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive Heart Failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by physical exam and chest X-ray.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Monitor daily weight and report any significant weight gain or shortness of breath. Order another echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is well-managed at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Continue to record blood pressures at home and report any elevated readings through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She states she was changing a light bulb on a ladder and stumbled, twisting her knee while trying to catch her fall. The incident occurred yesterday. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help much. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin. She has a past surgical history of a rhinoplasty. She denies any allergies.

EXAM:

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial meniscus area. Pain is elicited with valgus stress and knee flexion. Normal sensation in the lower extremity.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present.

IMPRESSION:

Acute medial meniscus strain.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her in a knee brace and provide crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for reevaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg, to take every 6 hours with food for two weeks.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

The patient states he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. He heard a pop in his lower back and had to lie down for about an hour before the pain was relieved. The pain has been persistent since the incident, which occurred on Saturday morning. The patient has tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, and icy heat without significant relief. He experienced tingling in his right toes until Sunday afternoon.

Regarding his diabetes, the patient admits to having a sweet tooth and not having the best diet recently. He has been compliant with his medications. The patient has been monitoring his blood pressure readings at home during the week but tends to forget on weekends. His blood pressure has been mostly under control. The patient's osteoarthritis in his knee has been manageable, with occasional aggravation from excessive activity or lifting heavy objects.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies weight loss. Endorses recent poor diet.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain. Endorses tingling in right toes.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic heart murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Examination of his back reveals pain to palpation at the lumbar spine. Pain with flexion and extension of the back. Negative straight leg raise.

Results:

Back x-ray, ordered and obtained in the office today, is unremarkable with good bony alignment and no fracture present.

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports feeling a 'pop' and immediate pain while lifting heavy boxes. He has tried Tylenol and ibuprofen without significant relief.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue icing the area and avoid strenuous activity. Refer to physical therapy for further evaluation and treatment.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has been compliant with medications, but his recent hemoglobin A1c was 8.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily. Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure readings have been running a little high.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has been managing his knee osteoarthritis well with no need for further workup at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam. He reports that his depression has been well-managed with Prozac, and he has not had any incidents recently. He is still working on managing his hypertension and admits to occasionally forgetting to take his Norvasc on weekends. He had a lobectomy a couple of years ago and has experienced some shortness of breath during humid weather while running.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat: Nasal congestion due to pollen.
• Cardiovascular: Occasional chest pounding during exertion.
• Respiratory: Shortness of breath with exertion.
• Psychiatric: Depression managed with Prozac.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neurological/Psychological: Appropriate mood and affect.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

Electrocardiogram: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerns related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression.
   • Medical Reasoning: Well-managed with Prozac.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily. Refill ordered.
   
2. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure is controlled, but patient admits to occasional non-compliance with Norvasc.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Norvasc as prescribed. Encourage compliance.
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.

3. Status post lobectomy.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is exercising regularly and has good breathing function.
   • Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon needed.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right index finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right index finger pain after a skiing accident. She reports that her finger was bent backward while skiing over moguls four days ago. She has tried ice and ibuprofen for pain relief, but the pain persists.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Miralax

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Constipation, appendectomy at age 18

EXAM:

Examination of the right index finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right index finger, 3 views obtained on today's visit show no fractures and normal alignment.

IMPRESSION:

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend an aluminum foam splint and a prescription for Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for one week. The patient is advised to call and return if the pain does not improve. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Abnormal labs, anemia, and fatigue.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Stephanie Diaz is a 49-year-old female with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure, kidney stones, and prior colonoscopy, who presents today for abnormal labs.

The patient reports she has been really tired and dizzy over the past couple of months. She reports these symptoms while walking a mile, going to work, and performing daily tasks. She denies any blood in her stools recently but notes she had blood in her stool about 3 years ago and had a colonoscopy for that. She denies any black, tarry stools, heavy menstrual bleeding, unintentional weight loss, or syncope.

Ms. Diaz had a colonoscopy about 3 years ago due to blood in her stool. This showed mild diverticulitis. She denies issues since that time.

Regarding her congestive heart failure, she states she is not doing well with her salt intake. This has been more of a struggle recently as she has been traveling a lot. She has noticed some swelling in her legs but nothing too extreme.

The patient denies recent issues with kidney stones. She denies low back pain, flank pain, or blood in her urine.

Ms. Diaz notes she has had some nasal congestion but attributes this to the season changing. She gets seasonal allergies but everything else has been okay. The patient denies fever, chills, sore throat, or cough.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fevers, chills, or weight loss. Endorses fatigue.
• Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion from allergies.
• Cardiovascular: Denies dyspnea.
• Respiratory: Denies cough, shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies hematochezia, melena.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses bilateral leg swelling.
• Neurological: Endorses dizziness.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: Trace to 1+ edema in the bilateral ankles.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram demonstrates decreased ejection fraction of 45%. Moderate mitral regurgitation.

Hemoglobin is 8.2.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Stephanie Diaz is a 49-year-old female with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure, kidney stones, and prior colonoscopy, who presents today for abnormal labs.

Anemia.
• Medical Reasoning: This is a new issue. Her recent hemoglobin level was low at 8.2, but she denies any signs of gastrointestinal bleeding or urinary tract bleeding, as well as any abnormal menstrual bleeding. Her colonoscopy from 3 years ago demonstrated mild diverticulosis.
• Additional Testing: We will order an anemia profile for further evaluation.
• Specialist Referrals: We will refer her back to gastroenterology for repeat evaluation with possible endoscopy and colonoscopy.

Congestive heart failure.
• Medical Reasoning: She has noticed some lower extremity edema. Her echocardiogram from 6 months ago demonstrated a reduced ejection fraction of 45%, as well as moderate mitral regurgitation.
• Medical Treatment: We will initiate Lasix 40 mg once daily, and continue with Toprol 50 mg daily and lisinopril 10 mg daily.
• Patient Education and Counseling: She should continue to limit her sodium intake. I advised her to monitor her daily weights and notify me if these start to increase.

Kidney stones.
• Medical Reasoning: She as asymptomatic denies any recent flare ups.
• Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged her to continue with dietary modifications and proper hydration. She will contact me with any questions or concerns.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for consultation regarding a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. The patient was referred by Dr. Henry Howard for possible surgical intervention. Mr. Ward initially presented to Dr. Howard on 3/1/21 with complaints of worsening headaches over the past few months. He denied any prior history of headaches. His past clinical history is unremarkable.

Workup for headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where the pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. Labs dated 3/3/21, including CBC, UNES, coagulation, and CRP, were all normal. Pituitary hormone profile demonstrated a low TSH, with all other results being normal. MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 revealed a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. No other abnormalities were noted.

The patient reports headaches located behind his eyes, described as a dull nagging ache. The onset was gradual, starting about three months ago and worsening over time. The headaches are worse in the morning and last a few hours at a time. The patient denies any other symptoms, such as feeling sick, fever, rashes, neck stiffness, numbness, weakness, or passing out. However, he has been bumping into door frames recently.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
None

SOCIAL HISTORY

Occupation: Computer programmer
Marital status: Married for 25 years
Recently bought a small house
Adopted, unknown family medical history

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

None

RESULTS

Brain MRI with contrast (3/4/21): Pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm.

ASSESSMENT

• Pituitary adenoma

PLAN

1. Recommend surgical intervention for excision and decompression of the pituitary fossa due to symptomatic optic chiasmal compression.
2. Refer the patient to an eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to assess peripheral vision before and after surgery.
3. Schedule surgery with the assistance of the surgery scheduler, Deborah.
4. Encourage the patient to call if they have any questions or concerns.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 52-year-old female who presents for follow-up after an ER visit for chest pain in October 2020. The patient experienced chest pain for four days, which resolved after her ER visit. She has not had any chest pain since then. The pain was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone, and was sharp in nature. The pain was worse with eating and she experienced difficulty swallowing during the episode. The patient has no family history of GI problems and has had her gallbladder removed several years ago.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Abdomen
• Lower Abdomen: No pain or tenderness upon palpation.
• Upper Abdomen: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 52-year-old female who presents for follow-up after an ER visit for chest pain. The chest pain has resolved and she has not experienced any additional episodes since October 2020. The ER visit ruled out heart issues and the patient mentioned a stressful job transition during the time of the chest pain episode.

Possible etiologies include GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal etiologies, and anxiety. The current suspicion is that the patient had an anxiety attack related to her job transition, with possible contribution from musculoskeletal etiologies.

The patient has elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any reoccurrence or change. An EGD was discussed but deferred due to the patient being asymptomatic for an extended period. The patient will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Evaluation of kidney function in a patient with Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome. She is a twin and was born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation. She has a history of feeding difficulties, reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, and physical therapy. She has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, who mentioned potential kidney issues related to her syndrome.

The patient's mother reports that Katherine has 8-10 wet diapers per day and drinks an adequate amount of fluids, including water and pea protein milk.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Gastrointestinal: Reflux, feeding difficulties.
• Musculoskeletal: Developmental delays, not walking independently yet.
• Neurological: History of Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting for evaluation of kidney function. Given the potential for congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract in patients with this syndrome, we will obtain a screening kidney ultrasound today. If there are abnormalities on the kidney ultrasound, we will determine next steps and future follow-up. The family lives in Dallas, Georgia, so her follow-up should be at the town center location.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana, a 35-year-old female, presents to the clinic today for evaluation of right wrist pain. The onset of her pain began when she slipped on the stairs while doing laundry and tried to catch herself with her right arm. She reports immediate pain and swelling in her right wrist. The patient rates her pain level as a 9 out of 10. She has been icing her wrist, using an ace wrap, and taking ibuprofen, which provided minimal relief. The patient denies any previous injuries to her right arm.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain.
Skin: Positive swelling in the right wrist.
Neurological: Reports slight tingling in fingers.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
RR: 20
Temp: 97.2°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Capillary refill is normal. 
NEURO: Normal sensation in fingers. 
MSK: Examination of the right wrist reveals obvious swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness on palpation. Pain on flexion, extension, abduction, and adduction. Limited ability to make a fist. Bony crepitus noted.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist reveals a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her symptoms are consistent with a Colles' fracture. I have recommended conservative treatment initially, including a brace for her right wrist. The patient will be scheduled for surgery as soon as possible. Post-surgery, the patient will be prescribed 50 mg of Ultram every six hours for pain management and will begin physical therapy a few weeks after surgery. The patient will wear the brace for six weeks.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in one month to assess her progress and discuss the possibility of going on vacation. If her pain does not improve or worsens, she will contact the office for further evaluation.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports slipping and falling while working on his property a week ago. He felt a pop in his right knee and has been experiencing pain and swelling since the incident.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, managed with 20 mg Lisinopril.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports needing help with dietary changes.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever.
Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.
Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg
Heart rate: Not provided
Respiration: Not provided
No fever.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort. Lungs clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Right knee: Pain to palpation on the medial aspect. Pain with flexion and extension. Edema and effusion present.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed in office today. These reveal no fractures or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Treatment: Ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and swelling. Knee brace for support. Ice for 20 minutes, 3-4 times a day.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Advised to elevate and rest the affected leg.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Referral to nutrition for dietary management.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any improvement. He denies any specific injury; however, he has been renovating his basement and suspects it might be related to that activity. The patient states he is very active and has experienced left shoulder pain before that usually resolves with Tylenol.

The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. The pain is constant and worsens when pressure is applied, such as when lying on the shoulder. He states the pain is primarily located in the left shoulder. The patient has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief. He denies any numbness or tingling in his left arm or fingers.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left knee pain. The onset of her pain is occasional, occurring less than once a day during walking. The patient reports that her knee "gives out" suddenly, causing her to feel unstable and at risk of falling. The pain is located internally in the whole kneecap area and resolves quickly. The patient denies any history of injury to the left knee and has not taken any medications for the pain.

The patient has a trip planned in the next month and is concerned about her ability to participate in line dancing due to her knee pain.

MEDICATIONS

The patient is currently taking Farxiga, Amlodipine, Lisinopril, and Hydrochlorothiazide for blood pressure management, and Metformin for diabetes management.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left knee pain and instability. Denies any history of injury to the left knee.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.

Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

MSK: Examination of the left knee: No ecchymosis, edema, or effusion. No pain to palpation of the left medial knee. No decreased range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain - likely arthritis.
2. Hypertension.
3. Diabetes Mellitus.

PLAN

1. For the left knee pain, prescribe Meloxicam 15 mg daily and initiate physical therapy to strengthen the muscles around the knee and prevent further problems.
2. Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension management and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Order a Hemoglobin A1c test to assess diabetes management and a lipid panel. Consider adjustments to Metformin dosage based on results.

The patient has no further questions. The nurse will assist in scheduling the echocardiogram.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Sore throat and cough.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer, currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports receiving support from family members and nursing staff.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently on cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue.
HENT: Reports sore throat and dry cough.
Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.

VITALS

Oxygen saturation: Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Face
- Examination: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Crackles bilaterally.

Skin
- Examination of Chest: Erythema on the anterior side of the left chest.

Lower Extremities
- Examination: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Lung cancer.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient is currently undergoing chemotherapy and radiation for stage three non-small cell lung cancer.
- Medical Treatment: Continue current chemotherapy regimen (cisplatin and etoposide) and radiation at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion of treatment to assess tumor response and potential for surgical intervention.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's cough and crackles on lung exam are likely due to radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe prednisone 40 mg daily for 5 days to reduce inflammation.

3. Painful swallowing.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's sore throat may be due to inflammation in the esophagus.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow four times a day to alleviate pain and facilitate eating and drinking.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low Immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports frequent colds during the winter season. Patient denies any history of immune deficiencies in the family. Patient recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Respiratory: Reports frequent colds that tend to linger.
Gastrointestinal: Denies any frequent diarrhea or abdominal infections.

VITALS

No fever or concerning vitals noted.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.
Respiratory: Lungs clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
Abdominal: Soft, non-tender.

LAB RESULTS

IgA deficiency noted in recent lab work.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. IgA deficiency.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a low IgA level, which is a common immunodeficiency. Patient does not appear to have frequent infections that would be concerning for a more severe immunodeficiency.
- Patient Education and Counseling: The nature of the diagnosis was discussed with the patient. I explained that IgA deficiency is a common immunodeficiency and that most people live their entire life without knowing they have it. I advised the patient to watch for infections that do not resolve or any changes in their abdominal tract, such as severe diarrhea. I also informed the patient to notify any healthcare providers if they need blood products, as there is a risk of a strong reaction due to the IgA deficiency.
- Medical Treatment: Additional blood work will be ordered to check for other antibody levels.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow pain. The patient has been experiencing right elbow pain for approximately four days, localized to the medial aspect of the elbow. The pain is described as a 6/10 in intensity and radiates slightly into the forearm. The patient denies any trauma or previous injury to the right elbow. The pain has been affecting his sleep and daily activities. He has tried ibuprofen with minimal relief.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient reports that he has been doing a lot of pottery during the pandemic.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that he has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Within normal limits.
MSK: Examination of the right elbow reveals pain to palpation over the medial epicondyle. Pain with pronation of the forearm. Pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right elbow were obtained and reviewed in the office today. These reveal no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Right medial epicondylitis.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we discussed the diagnosis of medial epicondylitis. The patient is advised to rest the affected elbow and wear a sling while awake. He is instructed to apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes, three times a day, and take ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours with food for a full week. The patient is advised to avoid pottery work for the next couple of weeks. A follow-up appointment is scheduled in one week to assess the patient's progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency department follow up.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Reports occasional chest pain.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath during physical activity.
Genitourinary: No issues reported.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: 98.7 degrees F
Heart Rate: 72 bpm
Oxygen Saturation: 96%

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: This appears to have been caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue making dietary modifications, including limiting his sodium intake. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding his diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily. 

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: This has been poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the importance of taking medications consistently and monitoring his diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue on Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 3 months.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Kidney stones.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of kidney stones. The patient was referred from his primary care physician. He has been experiencing sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain is intermittent and severe, making it difficult for him to find a comfortable position. He reports a burning sensation during urination and darker urine at times. He has taken Tylenol for the pain, but it has not been effective. The patient feels nauseated but has not vomited. He has a family history of kidney stones, with his father having had them, and he has had kidney stones before but was able to pass them.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

GI: Reports right abdominal pain and nausea.
GU: Reports burning sensation during urination and darker urine.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs. Positive CVA tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

The CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Right kidney stone.

PLAN

We reviewed the patient's CT results in detail today. I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively. I have prescribed the patient oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours for pain. He may continue to take Tylenol between the oxycodone doses for any breakthrough pain. The patient will be provided with a strainer to use when urinating to catch the stone for further testing. I have also recommended that we obtain a BMP, urinalysis, and urine culture to evaluate for any signs of infection.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me in 1 to 2 weeks to check on his progress. If his symptoms have not improved, we will discuss further treatment options including lithotripsy or ureteroscopy. The patient is advised to contact me if he experiences worsening symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing right foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a 79-year-old male who presents today for evaluation of a non-healing right foot ulcer. He reports having the ulcer for about six weeks, which started as a blister after wearing tight shoes. The blister later unroofed, revealing thick, soft, mushy skin with a foul smell and yellow drainage. He has been on antibiotics for six days, with some initial improvement, but now reports the wound has turned black around the edges and he is experiencing calf cramping. He also notes a red streak coming up the front part of his ankle along the inside portion of his calf muscle, which is hot to touch. He has been experiencing some coughing and shortness of breath in the last two days.

He is diabetic with an A1c of 6.7, which has been well-controlled for the past two years. However, his blood sugars have been trending higher in the past two weeks, with some spikes up to 500.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys hiking and recently tried a new pair of diabetic shoes.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking antibiotics for the foot ulcer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fever and chills.
Cardiovascular: Reports calf cramping.
Respiratory: Reports coughing and shortness of breath.
Skin: Reports non-healing right foot ulcer.
Neurological: No reported issues.

VITALS

Slight fever.
Blood pressure and heart rate within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses. Non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.
Skin: 2x2 cm necrotic wound on right heel with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythemia. No bony exposure. Foul odor present.
MSK: Pain and swelling in the calf muscle.

ASSESSMENT

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer, right foot
2. Diabetes
3. Possible cellulitis

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to his current symptoms. We discussed the following plan:

1. Order a test to check blood supply for the wound.
2. Perform debridement of the wound in the office today.
3. Obtain a culture of the wound and consider adjusting antibiotic therapy based on the results.
4. Monitor the redness and swelling in the calf closely and schedule a follow-up appointment in 7 days.
5. Encourage the patient to follow up with his endocrinologist to maintain good blood sugar control and keep his hemoglobin A1c below 7.

The patient understands the plan and has no further questions at this time.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports spending time outdoors, including hunting and yard work. Patient noticed a tick bite on the right knee over a week ago, with persistent burning sensation and discomfort.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever or chills.
Musculoskeletal: Denies additional joint pain.
Neurological: Reports headache and general malaise since tick bite.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension: Controlled with lisinopril.
Diabetes: Controlled with metformin.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs:
- Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
- Heart rate: 67 bpm
- Temperature: 98.4°F

Cardiovascular:
- Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops.

Respiratory:
- Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.

Musculoskeletal:
- Right knee: Erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance over right patella. Pain to palpation of right anterior knee. Full range of motion.

Skin:
- Bull's-eye rash over right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Tick bite and possible Lyme disease.
- Medical Reasoning: Presence of bull's-eye rash and tick bite on right knee.
- Medical Treatment: Start doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 3 weeks. Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm diagnosis.

2. Hypertension.
- Continue lisinopril 20 mg once daily. Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes.
- Continue metformin 1000 mg twice daily. Order hemoglobin A1c to assess long-term blood sugar control. Order basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed or if symptoms worsen.
